title: What were the Beatles’ ‘Granny Songs’? - Quora

response.answer_text: John used the term “Granny Music” to describe and put down quite a bit of Paul’s songs. John wanted to experiment and rock out. Paul was happy to write a broad range of music from hard rock to soft pop tunes. He prided himself on being able to write songs such as “Honey Pie” and create harder rock songs such as “Back In The U.S.S.R.”. As Paul put it, “same guy wrote those, me, I wrote those”. He appreciated his range. John did not suffer the easy on the ears pop songs that Paul began to put out and basically whined about them. So, a few examples would be: The Ballad Of Rocky Raccoon, Honey Pie, When I’m 64, Hello Goodbye, Your Mother Should Know, I’ve Just Seen A Face, Obladi-Oblada, Martha My Dear, I Will, and other bouncy teeny bop type songs. Paul went on to write many more of this type of music, such as Silly Love Songs and Just Another Day, and, as far as I’m concerned, so what! He enjoyed writing and creating all kinds of music. I appreciate Paul’s point. The range is remarkable. John can have his “I Am The Walrus.” I love it too. However, putting down what others create doesn’t seem fair, especially when that artist also creates amazing music such as Yesterday, Oh Darling, Maybe I’m Amazed, Back In The U.S.S.R., I’m Down, and on and on. Paul would only respond, “That’s just John being John.” I believe, though no one can ever know, that John would have softened his opinion about Paul’s Granny Music, and looked at the entire catalog by now. Age has a way of mellowing people a bit. What a shame that John’s opinion has to be frozen in time due to his tragic death. He doesn’t get the chance to grow and change with the times, and hence, is judged harshly for opinions he held briefly 50 years ago. His death is an ongoing tragedy because we were all cheated out of seeing him shine on and on and on and on. I still mourn his death and refuse to utter the name of his despicable murderer. I hate the fact that I can even remember it. It deserves no place in my brain.

That term was used by John to describe Paul’s songs, I don’t know when he started calling them “Granny’s Songs.” It seemed like it occurred later in their careers, as they were starting to change and eventually split up. I believe a few of those songs, according to what I have read, are Obla di Obla da, Yesterday, and after they split, some of Paul’s solo songs. In John’s “tribute” song to Paul “How do you Sleep”, seemingly written in anger, he referred to Paul’s “Another Day.” We will never really know how deep this anger was or even if it was just momentary. Paul’s response song, again I have read, was “Too many People” from his “Ram” album. As they got older and changed their styles before the Beatles split, you can see John’s style is totally different than Paul’s “Silly Love Songs” as John was writing things like “Working Class Hero.” Both styles had merit for sure, both styles very likable in their own way. I certainly would not call Paul’s songs “Granny Music” at all, just different than John’s, and ironically enough, possibly more successful as time went along.
